title: Feeling lonely? Study says loneliness increases your risk of developing dementia by 31% - Hindustan Times
summary:
Feeling lonely? Study says loneliness increases your risk of developing dementia by 31%

Date: Dec 15, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

A groundbreaking study published in Nature Mental Health reveals that loneliness is linked to a 31% increase in the risk of developing dementia, emphasizing its negative impact on brain health and cognitive function.

  • The study involved data from over 608,000 individuals globally.
  • Loneliness heightens the risk of developing Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia.
  • The study suggests chronic loneliness leads to cognitive decline and increased stress levels.
  • Loneliness can also result in milder cognitive difficulties, increasing by 15%.
“The finding is striking, as people who report feeling lonely are at a whopping 31% higher risk of developing dementia than those who don’t.”

This research underscores the importance of addressing loneliness as a significant public health concern, as it impacts mental and physical health, contributing to the risk of dementia and other cognitive impairments.

Tripura’s treasure: Fermented bamboo shoot emerges as a natural fat-fighter - EastMojo
summary:
Tripura’s treasure: Fermented bamboo shoot emerges as a natural fat-fighter

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Guwahati

Researchers from the Institute of Advanced Study in Science and Technology (IASST) have highlighted the anti-obesity potential of Melye-amiley, a fermented bamboo shoot from Tripura, showing its ability to promote fat browning and combat obesity.

  • The study, published in Food Frontiers, found that the water extract of Melye-amiley activates the AMPK pathway, promoting fat breakdown.
  • This bamboo shoot variety is part of a traditional preparation method that involves fermentation by lactic acid bacteria, enhancing its health benefits.
  • Key genes linked to fat metabolism were upregulated when fat cells were exposed to the extract.
  • The study also notes the presence of bioactive metabolites in the extract that may contribute to its anti-obesity effects.
  • Researchers emphasize the need for further studies to confirm these results in animal and human trials.
“With rising obesity rates worldwide, there is a growing interest in natural dietary interventions that can support weight management.” – Dr. Mojibur R. Khan

The findings suggest that traditional foods like Melye-amiley not only serve as sustenance but may also offer therapeutic benefits, thus paving the way for future research and potential development of nutraceutical products.

title: Understanding The Connection Between Quality Sleep And Stroke Risk - TheHealthSite
summary:
Understanding The Connection Between Quality Sleep And Stroke Risk

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: The Health Site

Recent studies highlight the importance of sleep in reducing the risk of stroke, urging both doctors and patients to consider sleep quality and disorders in stroke prevention strategies.

  • Stroke risk is prevalent globally, with WHO estimating one in four individuals will experience a stroke in their lifetime.
  • Traditional risk factors include hypertension, diabetes, and lifestyle issues such as obesity.
  • New research indicates sleep quality and disorders significantly influence stroke risk, along with duration.
  • Too little sleep (under six hours) and excessive sleep (over nine hours) are both linked to an increased risk of stroke.
  • Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) is a critical risk factor, increasing the likelihood of stroke two to three times.
  • Insomnia and Restless Leg Syndrome (RLS) contribute to poorer sleep quality and higher stroke risk.
“Each apnea episode results in a brief drop in blood oxygen levels, causing blood pressure to spike.”

Overall, prioritizing quality sleep can play a vital role in stroke prevention strategies and improving brain health.

title: Why Does Winter Worsen Asthma Symptoms—And How Can You Fight Back? - Times Now
summary:
Why Does Winter Worsen Asthma Symptoms—And How Can You Fight Back?

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Times Now

Asthma sufferers often find winter to be particularly challenging due to cold, dry air and indoor allergens, leading to increased symptoms and flare-ups. This article explores the reasons behind these worsened conditions and offers management strategies.

  • Cold air can irritate airways and increase mucus production.
  • Indoor allergens such as dust mites, mold spores, and pet dander peak during colder months as people stay indoors.
  • Respiratory infections, including flu and colds, are more common in winter and can trigger asthma episodes.
  • Medications for cold and flu can sometimes worsen asthma symptoms.
  • Staying hydrated, practicing good hygiene, and dressing warmly can help manage asthma in winter.
  • It's important to have a flu vaccine and carry an inhaler, especially for outdoor activities.
“Viral diseases such as the flu and the common cold rise in the winter and are a primary trigger for many individuals with asthma.” - Dr. Sushrut Ganpule

In conclusion, managing asthma during winter requires a combination of lifestyle adjustments, awareness of triggers, and proactive care, such as regular communication with a healthcare provider.

How intermittent fasting could lead to hair loss - The Indian Express
summary:
How intermittent fasting could lead to hair loss

Publication Date: December 13, 2023

Source: Cell Press

Kilos are not the only thing that intermittent fasting will help you shed. A new study shows that the wildly popular weight-loss method could also inhibit hair growth.

  • Intermittent fasting is a time-restricted diet where participants consume calories in an 8-12 hour window.
  • Benefits include weight loss, increased insulin sensitivity, and improved diabetes control.
  • A 2023 survey reported that over 12% of respondents in the US are practicing intermittent fasting.
  • Research linked intermittent fasting to a 91% higher risk of death from cardiovascular disease.
  • Disruptions in sleep cycles and gastric issues are also associated with intermittent fasting.
  • A recent study shows a link between intermittent fasting and hair loss by inhibiting hair follicle regeneration.
“Commonly used intermittent fasting regimens inhibit hair follicle regeneration by selectively inducing apoptosis [programmed cell death] in activated hair follicle stem cells (HFSCs)…”

Researchers found that mice on intermittent fasting exhibited slower hair regeneration, and similar effects were observed in a small human trial, albeit likely less severe in humans.

The study suggests that hair growth inhibition occurs because HFSCs cannot handle the oxidative stress from switching energy sources during fasting.

“During fasting, adipose tissue starts to release free fatty acids...but these stem cells don’t have the right machinery to use them,” - Bing Zhang, senior author and stem cell biologist.

Further research is needed to understand the effects of intermittent fasting on hair loss across different individuals.

title: Poliovirus found in wastewater in Spain, Germany and Poland: All you need to know - Deccan Herald
summary:
Poliovirus found in wastewater in Spain, Germany and Poland: All you need to know

Publication Date: 15 December 2024, 08:59 IST

By: Mariachiara Di Cesare, Francis Hassard for The Conversation

Recent detections of poliovirus in wastewater across Spain, Germany, and Poland raise concerns for public health, despite no confirmed infections reported. This serves as a reminder of the importance of vaccination efforts to prevent potential outbreaks.

  • Polio is a highly contagious disease that can lead to paralysis and death.
  • Since 1988, global poliovirus cases have decreased by over 99%, with Pakistan and Afghanistan remaining endemic.
  • Detection of the virus in wastewater is a warning of possible vaccination coverage gaps.
  • Wastewater surveillance provides crucial insights for early disease detection, particularly in under-immunised populations.
  • In 2023, Europe achieved polio immunisation coverage of about 95% for one-year-olds, but gaps remain.
  • Reports indicate that 30% of countries have vaccination coverage below 80%.
  • The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted vaccination programs, impacting public health efforts against polio.
“Wastewater-based surveillance provides public health authorities with another weapon in the fight against infectious diseases.”

In conclusion, the detection of poliovirus in wastewater emphasizes the need for continuous vaccination efforts and surveillance to ensure public health safety and prevent the resurgence of this dangerous disease.

title: India Achieves Milestone in Malaria Control with 69% Drop in Cases and Deaths: WHO Report - Pratidin Time
summary:
India Achieves Milestone in Malaria Control with 69% Drop in Cases and Deaths: WHO Report

Publication Date: December 15, 2024

Source: The Publive

India has made significant strides in combating malaria, achieving a 69% reduction in both cases and deaths, according to the latest World Malaria Report released by the WHO.

  • India exited the high burden high incidence (HBHI) group in 2024.
  • From 2017 to 2023, malaria cases decreased from 64 lakh to 20 lakh (69% reduction).
  • Malaria deaths dropped from 11,100 to 3,500 (68% decrease).
  • India accounts for half of the malaria cases in Southeast Asia.
  • Between 2000 and 2023, malaria cases reduced by 82.4%.
  • Indoor Residual Spraying (IRS) coverage decreased in 2023, protecting 30 lakh fewer people.
“The WHO report recognized India’s efforts, highlighting the crucial role of community health workers, particularly women, in reaching remote populations and significantly lowering malaria cases.”

Despite the progress made in malaria control, the report warns that the global malaria target for 2030 is off track, urging for more investments and actions in high-burden countries.

title: Health News Live December 15, 2024 : Ultimate fat burning guide to help you achieve healthy weight loss fast: Nutritionist shares top 8 recommendations - Hindustan Times
Ultimate fat burning guide to help you achieve healthy weight loss fast: Nutritionist shares top 8 recommendations - Hindustan Times
summary:
Ultimate Fat Burning Guide to Help You Achieve Healthy Weight Loss Fast: Nutritionist Shares Top 8 Recommendations

Publication Date: December 15, 2024

Source: Hindustan Times

Nutritionist and lifestyle coach Raksha Lulla has shared a video outlining eight easy and sustainable habits for weight loss that can help individuals burn calories and achieve their health goals without feeling restricted.

  • 1. Eat till spaciousness: Stop when your stomach feels light and not heavy.
  • 2. Drink water from a glass: Stay hydrated without waiting to feel thirsty.
  • 3. Take magnesium glycinate: A nightly supplement that supports vitamin levels with a doctor's guidance.
  • 4. Add ghee to carbohydrates: Enhances fullness while moderating glycemic index.
  • 5. Walk for no reason: Engage in leisurely walking without specific goals.
  • 6. Add seasonal vegetables: Incorporate nutrient-rich vegetables for balanced nutrition.
  • 7. Strength train at least once a week: Focus on full-body exercises without explosive movements.
  • 8. Practice 4-7-8 breathing: Use this technique to center yourself each morning.
“This is the ultimate fat-burning guide that will make you the version of yourself – achieve a healthy weight loss and keep it off too!” - Raksha Lulla

This comprehensive guide emphasizes that weight loss should be sustainable and enjoyable, not a chore.

Can drinking coffee boost longevity? - Medical News Today
summary:
Coffee May Help Prolong Lifespan by Almost 2 Years, on Average

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: Medical News Today

A new review study suggests that regular coffee consumption may increase a person's lifespan by an average of 1.8 healthy years, reinforcing the beverage's positive health effects.

  • Coffee is one of the most popular beverages worldwide, with around 2 million cups consumed daily.
  • A recent review from the University of Coimbra highlights coffee's potential health benefits.
  • The study, funded by the Institute for Scientific Information on Coffee, analyzed over 50 studies on coffee consumption.

“Moderate intake of coffee was found to decrease the incidence of several chronic diseases.” – Rodrigo Cunha, PhD.

In conclusion, regular coffee consumption is associated with healthier aging; however, it is essential to consider individual health needs and consumption patterns.

title: Are you living with eczema? It’s time to get the care you deserve - Philadelphia Sunday Sun
summary:
Are you living with eczema? It’s time to get the care you deserve

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: The Philadelphia Sunday Sun

For millions in the U.S., eczema remains a chronic skin condition often misunderstood and poorly treated, particularly in individuals with skin of color, highlighting the urgent need for greater awareness and tailored healthcare.

  • Approximately 16.5 million people in the U.S. live with eczema, a condition that causes severe itchiness and can lead to skin damage.
  • Symptoms can result in self-isolation, anxiety, and depression, particularly among those with darker skin tones where symptoms can be less visible.
  • Research indicates Black Americans often develop more severe cases of eczema, yet experience barriers to care due to underrepresentation in medical research.
  • Lilly is implementing initiatives to educate healthcare providers about treating patients with diverse skin tones and addressing related health disparities.
  • Efforts include conducting targeted research, providing educational resources, and empowering patient voices in the healthcare conversation.
“I wasn’t aware of research on skin conditions like eczema in my community... We need doctors to have more education on how this disease can affect a patient’s mental health.” - April

To improve care for eczema sufferers, particularly those with skin of color, there is a pressing need for cultural sensitivity and tailored education in dermatology. Partnerships between patients and providers can foster better understanding and more effective treatment options.

Top 5 immunity-boosting drinks for winter - Hindustan Times
summary:
Top 5 immunity-boosting drinks for winter

Publication Date: December 13, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

This article presents five delicious beverages aimed at enhancing immunity during the winter season, highlighting their health benefits and ingredients.

  • Turmeric Golden Milk: A warming blend of milk with turmeric, black pepper, and honey rich in antioxidants and anti-inflammatory properties.
  • Ginger Lemon Tea: A zesty mix of ginger, lemon, and honey offering a high dose of vitamin C, perfect for soothing sore throats.
  • Tulsi and Peppermint Tea: A calming infusion that combines tulsi and peppermint to boost immunity and alleviate nasal congestion.
  • Spiced Apple Cider: A festive drink made from simmered apple juice with cinnamon, cloves, and star anise, packed with antioxidants.
  • Amla and Ginger Juice: A refreshing juice made from fresh amla and ginger, rich in vitamin C, helping to strengthen immunity and detoxify the body.
"High in vitamin C, amla juice strengthens immunity and detoxifies the body." - Hindustan Times

In conclusion, integrating these immunity-boosting drinks into your winter routine can help maintain health and wellness during the colder months.

title: From Alia Bhatt to Deepika Padukone: 5 celebrity skincare routines you can follow - Health shots
summary:
From Alia Bhatt to Deepika Padukone: 5 celebrity skincare routines you can follow

Published On: 15 Dec 2024, 10:30 am IST

Discover the secrets to radiant skin with these celebrity-inspired morning skincare routines. Know how to protect your skin like a star.

  • Alia Bhatt emphasizes gentle cleansing, toning, hydration, and sunscreen to achieve glowing skin.
  • Kriti Sanon starts her routine with ice water to reduce puffiness, followed by cleansing and hydrating products.
  • Deepika Padukone shares her moisturizing and sun protection techniques to maintain her skin’s health.
  • Madhuri Dixit uses mild cleansers and natural toners to refresh her skin and always applies sunscreen.
  • Kiara Advani follows a simple but effective regimen prioritizing gentle cleansing, hydration, and sun protection.
"These skincare routines contain simple ideas that everyone can follow in their everyday practice." - Article Summary

In conclusion, following the simple yet effective skincare routines of these celebrities can help achieve healthy, glowing skin. Remember, a blend of proper skincare, hydration, and sun protection is key.
